author: By Vjosa Isai
title: A New Speaker for Canada After a Misstep That ‘Deeply Embarrassed Parliament’
description: The House of Commons will elect a new speaker on Tuesday, following the resignation of its current speaker under historic circumstances.
content: It was President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine’s first trip to Canada since Russia’s full-scale invasion of his country. And its high point was an address by Mr. Zelensky to a joint session of Parliament last week that provoked waves of applause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: The One Place I Can’t Go
description: Regions we skirt in our private maps of the world.
content: Various regions we skirt in our private maps of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: DiFi, Breaking Into the Boys’ Club
description: The “Year of the Woman” turned into three decades for this gutsy woman.
content: WASHINGTON — I’ve always said that the Washington Monument is an apt symbol, a Freudian obelisk redolent of all the male egos that have shaped our capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: Two Books About Grit and Grime
description: A Hollywood memoir; a call-girl novel
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: No Pilgrimages to Her Gravesite
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 30, 2023.
content: “They’re very sharp, they’re bitter. There’s too much truth in those books.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Why Evergrande’s Problems Are Only Getting Worse
description: The Chinese property developer’s efforts to restructure more than $300 billion in debt are being complicated by criminal investigations into current and former executives.
content: For months, the unwinding of China Evergrande, the world's most indebted property developer, played out like a slow-moving train crash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Lori Teresa Yearwood, Journalist of Life on the Edge, Dies at 57
description: Once a reporter for The Miami Herald, she became homeless. She later returned to journalism, calling on her experience to cover the continuing homelessness crisis.
content: Lori Teresa Yearwood, a journalist who after an excruciating spiral into two years of homelessness returned to reporting and wrote both about her ordeal and about people dealing with similar economic hardships, died on Sept. 17 at her home in Salt Lake City. She was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How Mary Harron, Film Director, Spends Her Sundays
description: The director of “Dalíland” and “American Psycho” loves the Cloisters, secondhand furniture from Housing Works, and New York’s old-school movie theaters.
content: The director and screenwriter Mary Harron is interested in people who have done terrible things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and John Tully
title: When a Drug Crisis Collides With the Campaign Trail
description: Republicans are making big promises about combating fentanyl. Their words ring hollow to some who know too much about the drug’s deadly toll.
content: The official toxicology report states that Andrea Cahill’s son died at 19 years old from an accidental fentanyl overdose. But more than three years after Tyler Cahill’s death in his childhood bedroom, she doesn’t believe that. It was a poisoning, she says, and there is no question about whom to blame: “the cartels.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Schoenfeld
title: Shohei Ohtani’s Impossible, Unrivaled, Bittersweet Season
description: It might have been the greatest year of individual achievement in major-league history. Will we ever see anything like it again?
content: In late August, a few days after the remnants of Hurricane Hilary hit the Southern California coast as only the second tropical storm there in recorded history, the Los Angeles Angels played a doubleheader at home against the Cincinnati Reds — a regularly scheduled game and a game that had previously been postponed. In the first inning of the opener, Shohei Ohtani came to the plate with a runner on first base. With his first swing, he smashed a fastball 116 miles per hour over the billboards with the Japanese ads in right field and into the stands, a computer-estimated 442 feet away. It was not just Ohtani’s 44th home run, the most in the American League at the time; it was an especially prodigious one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Ed Begley Jr. Can Tell You the 3 Best Comedies of All Time
description: The actor and environmentalist considered hiring a ghostwriter for help with his memoir, then realized as he was writing things down, “This is too much fun.”
content: Is there anyone in Hollywood that Ed Begley Jr. doesn’t know?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Talbot
title: Running San Francisco Made Dianne Feinstein
description: During her decade running the cantankerous city, she managed to steer it between a liberal, freewheeling future and its more conservative traditions.
content: When I was interviewing Senator Dianne Feinstein in 2011 for a book about San Francisco’s tumultuous history from the 1960s to the ’80s, she suddenly began to tear off her microphone and terminate the exchange. My offense? I asked about her decision as mayor of the city to veto a 1982 ordinance that would have extended health insurance benefits to live-in partners of municipal employees, including lesbians and gay men. I managed to coax the irate Ms. Feinstein back into her chair, but she had clearly drawn a line: I’m ready to leave whenever I don’t like the direction this is headed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Halloween in New York: Things to Do in October
description: Our guide for what to do this month in the city, from the Village parade to screenings of horror movies and kid-friendly haunted houses.
content: Recently, a guy in front of me at the checkout had just two things in his shopping basket: giant bags of Twizzlers and a naughty nurse costume. My first thought was: I want to go to that party. My second was: I’m way behind on a Halloween game plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: The Harvard Professor and the Bloggers
description: When Francesca Gino, a rising academic star, was accused of falsifying data — about how to stop dishonesty — it didn’t just torch her career. It inflamed a crisis in behavioral science.
content: The day almost two years ago when Harvard Business School informed Francesca Gino, a prominent professor, that she was being investigated for data fraud also happened to be her husband’s 50th birthday. An administrator instructed her to turn in any Harvard-issued computer equipment that she had by 5 p.m. She canceled the birthday celebration she had planned and walked the machines to campus, where a University Police officer oversaw the transfer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Sept. 23-29
description: Bad luck came in threes (and a seven) in this week’s toughest tests.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Schwartz
title: Pain Was Her Drug
description: In “Brutalities: A Love Story,” Margo Steines chronicles her lifelong fixation with being hurt — and shows herself some compassion.
content: BRUTALITIES: A Love Story, by Margo Steines
source.name: The New York Times

title: Raising Kids in Single-Parent Households
description: Readers react to a guest essay arguing that the growing number of such households is bad for the children.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner and Erin Schaff
title: For Black Mothers, Birthing Centers, Once a Refuge, Become a Battleground
description: Some say the facilities, which focus on autonomy in childbirth, could lead to better health outcomes — but officials are tightening rules, citing risk.
content: Gabrielle Glaze felt scolded and shamed when she delivered her first son in a Birmingham, Ala., hospital, forced to observe strict rules about lying stationary through her contractions and enduring countless cervical checks from “total strangers” who seemed disappointed by her body’s progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: After 7 Weeks in Burn Unit, Another Maui Fire Victim Dies
description: Laurie Allen had to run through a wall of flame to escape the August wildfire. Doctors went to extraordinary lengths to try to save her.
content: As thousands of people rushed to flee the raging wildfire that swept through the Hawaiian town of Lahaina, a flaming branch crashed to the roadway ahead of Laurie Allen’s car as she tried to escape. With the fire closing in, she knew that her only hope was to get out and run — through the inferno.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Model-Off-Duty Style Evolves
description: Some of the best looks worn by models at Milan Fashion Week weren’t on the runways.
content: A statement that might surprise no one: Many models who make a living by wearing clothes also have great personal style. But the “off duty” wardrobe lots of them have been known for — which was often some combination of white T-shirt and jeans — has evolved. This evolution was on display at Milan Fashion Week, where some of the most interesting looks worn by models were on the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Valerie Hopkins
title: Ukraine’s War of Drones Runs Into an Obstacle: China
description: As the war with Russia stretches on, so too does a contest to make more and deadlier flying machines. That means a fight over global electronics supply chains that run through China.
content: Surrounded by rooms filled with stacks of cluster munitions and half-made thermobaric bombs, a soldier from Ukraine’s 92nd Mechanized Brigade recently worked on the final part of a deadly supply chain that stretches from China’s factories to a basement five miles from the front lines of the war with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abigail Santamaria
title: Two Books Explore the Lives of Witches
description: In Allyson Stone’s “Ashes and Stones” and Diana Helmuth’s “The Witching Year,” authors confront ancient stereotypes through modern eyes.
content: From “MacBeth’s” weird sisters to Snow White’s evil stepmother, witches have long enchanted our collective imagination. They are dangerously seductive; they are old hags; deceitful; estranged from society; unmarried and childless. Almost always, they are women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola, Katie Rogers and Cora Engelbrecht
title: Why Is the U.S. Telling Serbia to Move Troops From the Kosovo Border?
description: Washington called for the troops’ rollback days after an attack at a monastery in northern Kosovo. Here’s what to know.
content: As the White House called on Friday for Serbia to roll back its troops amassed on the Kosovo border, United States officials described that military presence as “destabilizing” and a worrying sign of potential escalation in the tensions between Serbia and Kosovo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maahil Mohamed and Mujib Mashal
title: Maldives President Is Defeated, in Vote Overshadowed by India and China
description: Mohamed Muizzu, the mayor of the capital city pushing for closer ties with China, won a runoff against the pro-India incumbent, Ibrahim Mohamed Solih.
content: President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih of the Maldives was defeated in the presidential runoff on Saturday, in a race that was proving to be as much a referendum on the competition between India and China for influence as it was a chance to determine the small island nation’s next leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Film Adaptations
description: Jeffrey Lease produces an intricate, action-packed debut.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: How Did the Government Get Near a Shutdown?
description: Any deal to keep it open would have to be bipartisan, since the Senate and White House are controlled by Democrats, and the House by Republicans.
content: The House of Representatives passed a short-term spending measure on Saturday. If the Senate also passes the bill, the federal government could avoid a shutdown that would have come at midnight on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Why Unions Are Good for America
description: Yes, they overreach at times, but as they weakened, so did our social fabric.
content: As the United Automobile Workers strike continues, we’re likely to hear grumbling about labor unions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Evelyn Fox Keller, Who Turned a Feminist Lens on Science, Dies at 87
description: Trained as a physicist and biologist, she argued that science had become gendered, with a narrow masculine framework that distorted inquiry.
content: Evelyn Fox Keller, a theoretical physicist, a mathematical biologist and, beginning in the late 1970s, a feminist theorist who explored the way gender pervades and distorts scientific inquiry, died on Sept. 22 at an assisted living home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: U2 Returns, in Las Vegas Limbo
description: In the inaugural show at Sphere, a $2.3 billion venue, a band unafraid of pomp and spectacle was sometimes out-pomped and out-spectacled.
content: Perhaps the true gift of Las Vegas is how it renders the extraordinary as mundane. A place where the simulacrum of glamour available to everyone ensures no one gets the real thing. A city responsible for billions of dollars of commerce that has the texture of a Fisher-Price play set. A hub for some of the country’s most beloved performers that blurs the lines between superstar D.J.s, cheeky magicians and bona fide vocal heroes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 30, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 30, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about unresolved traumas left by the 1989 Romanian revolution misstated the fate of a security agent who interrogated a participant at a protest. The agent, who later became a municipal official, is still alive and was declared a hero, not a martyr, of the revolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Where German Cars Falter, E-Bikes Gain in Power
description: E-bikes sales in Germany have jumped, as drivers, suppliers and even automakers embrace their role in the future of transportation.
content: Germany’s automakers are facing steep challenges as they convert to battery-powered lineups and confront rising competition from China. But business is booming in another corner of the German transport industry: e-bikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: In an Israeli Oasis, a Model for Peace, if Messy and Imperfect
description: In a small village, Jews and Arabs have chosen to live side by side, share power and imagine a more hopeful future. But even here, the agonies of the conflict can’t be escaped entirely.
content: From a distance, the cemetery looks much like any other in Israel, but examine the tombs closely and a startling fact is revealed: Here are buried Jews, Muslims and Christians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Iraq Wedding Fire’s Death Toll Rises, as Investigators Point to Safety Violations
description: The wedding hall lacked emergency exits and a sprinkler system, and was made of materials that seemed similar to those used in Grenfell Tower in London, where a fire in 2017 killed 79 people.
content: The sounds of mourning have coursed through the small Christian town of Qaraqosh in northern Iraq since late Tuesday, when a fire destroyed a wedding hall in the middle of a reception, touching not only this village, but Iraq’s entire Christian community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Rosenblatt
title: What They Don’t Tell You About Getting Old
description: Getting old is no joke. It just looks funny.
content: I recently turned 83, and while there are many joys to getting older, getting out of taxis is not one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Three Jamie Wyeth Paintings Destroyed in a Maine Village Fire
description: A fire that broke out on Wednesday burned multiple waterfront buildings, including an art gallery with works by members of the Wyeth family of artists.
content: A fire in a Maine village on Wednesday destroyed multiple original paintings by the renowned painter Jamie Wyeth of the Wyeth family of artists, along with several waterfront buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Golden Bachelor, Boomer Bait?
description: “The Golden Bachelor” is part of broadcast networks’ efforts to cater to their mostly older audience.
content: In September 1985, a new hit premiered on NBC. The network envisioned a show like nothing else on TV. “Take some women around 60. Society has written them off, has said they’re over the hill,” the pitch to producers went. “We want them to be feisty as hell and having a great time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Gwyneth Paltrow Looks Back at 15 Years of Goop and More: ‘Don’t Put Me on Truth Serum.’
description: The actress and entrepreneur knows she and her company are cultural lightning rods.
content: “I don’t think that anybody thinks I actually operate my company,” Gwyneth Paltrow said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds and Alessandro Marazzi Sassoon
title: At Carter’s Birthday Party, Rescheduled in Case of Shutdown, a Wary Celebration
description: Anticipating its closure, the Carter library moved up celebrations for the former president, who is turning 99. As partygoers played games and ate cake, some called the deadlock in Congress “shameful.”
content: There was trivia, doll-making and a chocolate marble cake that was gone in minutes. Hundreds of admirers of Jimmy Carter celebrated his 99th birthday in Atlanta on Saturday at the presidential library and museum named for him, after organizers moved the festivities up one day earlier than his actual birthday because of the threat of the government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: In Feinstein, San Francisco Had an Endless Champion
description: Dianne Feinstein’s life was inseparable from the fortunes and tragedies of the city over nine decades.
content: Even as a senator, Dianne Feinstein didn’t hesitate to share her gripes about San Francisco’s uneven sidewalks and dirty streets with the mayors who succeeded her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle and Melissa Guerrero
title: Amal Clooney, Anne Hathaway and Jon Hamm Hit the Fall Galas in New York
description: The Clooneys hosted the Albies, and the New York Philharmonic and Metropolitan Opera held opening night galas.
content: On Thursday night, in rainy Midtown Manhattan, a parade of black cars deposited some of Hollywood’s most celebrated figures at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue for the second annual Albies, a benefit hosted by the Clooney Foundation for Justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Alyssa Pointer
title: In a ‘City Too Busy to Hate,’ New Attention to an Overlooked Race Massacre
description: Researchers say that mob violence against Black residents in 1906 played a role in Atlanta’s evolution, whether residents knew it or not.
content: The Rev. Charles Hamilton stood on a narrow median in downtown Atlanta on a busy Monday morning, cars whooshing by just a few feet away on either side. With the modest help of a microphone, he was making a largely futile attempt to cut through the noise and bustle with a message for a city that never slows down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sewell Chan
title: Impeachments, #MeToo, Trump: Running The Washington Post During a Decade of Turmoil
description: “Collision of Power,” Martin Baron’s memoir of his tenure as the paper’s executive editor, is a gripping chronicle of politics and journalism in a period of instability for both.
content: About a year and a half after acquiring The Washington Post for $250 million in 2013, Jeff Bezos told its executives to come up with a slogan for it. “An idea I want to belong to,” was the directive from Bezos, the founder of Amazon. “I’d easily pay $100 to be associated with that idea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Reassert Need for Gag Order on Trump in Elections Case
description: Federal prosecutors argued that the former president has continued to make threatening statements after their initial request to limit his public discussion of the case.
content: Federal prosecutors on Friday reasserted the need to impose a gag order on former President Donald J. Trump in the case accusing him of seeking to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: In Texas, Mums Rival Football as the Big Homecoming Attraction
description: The elaborate adornments have come a long way since the days of simple chrysanthemum corsages.
content: The J.J. Pearce High School homecoming football game was underway on a hot, breezy Friday night. Up in the bleachers, tubas swayed from side to side as if waving hello, and bare backs rippled with red and blue paint that spelled, “Go Mustangs!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler and Claire Moses
title: Pandemic Relief Funding for Child Care Is Ending. What Now?
description: More than 80 percent of licensed child care providers in the United States received the grants, which they used to pay bills and raise wages for staff.
content: As the U.S. government hurtles toward a near-certain shutdown this weekend, a different kind of high-stakes shutdown will happen tonight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria M. Walker
title: This Kind of Luxury Is Not for Sale, but You Can Rent It
description: A developer has turned to rental buildings, driven by interest rates that preclude even wealthy house hunters from buying.
content: The Anagram Columbus Circle has all the opulence expected of a new luxury building: cabinets and bathroom vanities manufactured in Italy, appliances from Bosch and Wolf, a gym, a penthouse terrace that can be reserved for private events and guests, and co-working spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By María Sánchez Díez
title: Gabriela Wiener Does Not Care if You Don’t See Her Writing as Literature
description: The Peruvian author wants to “decolonize” everything — starting with her body and her family. Her latest book, “Undiscovered,” investigates the 19th-century European explorer that shares her last name.
content: When the Peruvian writer Gabriela Wiener was a child, she dreaded school trips to museums in Lima, the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Nancy Van de Vate, Composer and Advocate for Women in Music, Dies at 92
description: An American who settled in Vienna, she had a prolific career in contemporary classical music and broke gender barriers in her field.
content: Early in her career, Nancy Van de Vate, a celebrated modernist composer, would tell people about her work and sometimes be met with dismissive questions like “Do you write songs for children?” And though she often won competitions that she had entered anonymously, her daughter Katherine Van de Vate said, she rarely won when she entered them under her own name, a dynamic she attributed to gender discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Hurubie Meko
title: After Intense Floods, New York City Lurches Back to Life
description: The city’s transit systems had resumed service, with some delays, as the rain abated on Saturday. The governor warned that climate change was making severe storms more common.
content: After record-breaking rains swamped the subway, grounded flights and flooded streets in New York City and the surrounding region on Friday, New Yorkers resumed their routines the next morning. Rain showers continued on Saturday, putting some areas at risk of further flooding, but they were expected to taper off by the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: One Way to Help Teacher Salaries Go Further: Free Housing
description: With affordable housing scarce, one Connecticut child care center is providing its staff with rent-free homes designed by Yale architecture students.
content: Kristen Calderon was making about $37,000 a year as an early childhood educator in New Haven, Conn. It was more than the state’s average salary for the job but given the high cost of housing, it was barely enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: At Least 5 Dead in Crash That Led to Toxic Gas Leak
description: A tractor-trailer carrying anhydrous ammonia overturned and ruptured, leading to an evacuation of residents of Teutopolis, Ill.
content: Five people died after a crash involving multiple vehicles, including a tractor-trailer carrying anhydrous ammonia that overturned in Illinois on Friday night, leading to a leak of the toxic gas and prompting residents within a one-mile radius of the crash site to evacuate, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Conducting Lessons: How Bradley Cooper Became Leonard Bernstein
description: For “Maestro,” Cooper learned from top conductors like Gustavo Dudamel and Yannick Nézet-Séguin — and by stealth in concert halls or from the orchestra pit.
content: On a late-spring day in 2018, when the New York Philharmonic was deep in rehearsals of a Strauss symphony, an unexpected visitor showed up at the stage door of David Geffen Hall, the Philharmonic’s home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: A Brief History of Consequential Deaths in Congress
description: Lawmakers’ deaths have sometimes helped to flip partisan control. With an aging, narrowly divided Senate, it could be a possibility again.
content: Dianne Feinstein, who died on Thursday at 90, was the first senator to die in office since John McCain in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: ‘My Body Was Poisoned’: Biden’s Lead Pipe Removal Plan Faces Hurdles
description: A string of unexpected impediments could delay the administration’s timeline on an issue that is central to its effort to address racial disparities.
content: In her basement on the South Side of Chicago, Crystal Vance beamed a flashlight onto the water source for her home: a rusted and leaking lead pipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: A President on a Picket Line
description: Biden and Trump see solidarity very differently.
content: On Tuesday, Joe Biden became the first sitting American president to walk a picket line. Specifically, he joined strikers and spoke briefly outside a General Motors facility in Van Buren Township, Mich., where hundreds of striking autoworkers were demanding their fair share of the profits they produced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: ‘Close to the Line’: Why More Seniors Are Living in Poverty
description: Benefits extended earlier in the coronavirus pandemic have been rolled back. But many older Americans are not taking advantage of the aid still available.
content: It has never been easy for Mary Cole to support herself and the 19-year-old grandson who lives with her in Bristol, Va., on her monthly $914 Supplemental Security Income check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Gorgeous Thieboudienne, Maple-Butter Roast Chicken and Gochujang Potato Stew
description: Satisfying (and simple) recipes for feeding friends and family.
content: As Yewande Komolafe writes in her recipe, thieboudienne (above), often referred to as the national dish of Senegal, is particularly lovely to assemble with friends — a perfect meal for a crisp, autumn Sunday supper. Have one friend find the fish and put another on vegetable duty; you’ll provide the pantry staples (broken rice, tomato paste and spices) and a shallow pot. Two easy hours of searing and simmering later, you’ll dig into a complete one-pot meal of herbaceous fish, tender vegetables and richly seasoned rice. And we do mean dig — you’ll want to reach that xońe (or xoñe), the crunchy bits of rice stuck to the bottom of the pot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Karoun Demirjian
title: For Biden, Menendez’s Troubles May Clear Foreign Policy Roadblocks
description: As the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Menendez bucked Democratic colleagues — and presidents — on matters ranging from Cuba to Iran.
content: When the Biden administration relaxed some travel restrictions on Americans visiting Cuba in May of last year, Senator Robert Menendez was having none of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Hunter-Gatherers Were Making Baskets 9,500 Years Ago, Researchers Say
description: Dozens of items that were found in a cave in southern Spain more than a century ago date from the Mesolithic era and are much older than previously thought, according to a new study.
content: Hunter-gatherer societies on the Iberian Peninsula were making sophisticated baskets with decorative geometric patterns 9,500 years ago, more than 2,000 years earlier than previously thought, researchers in Spain have reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: With Climate Change, Smaller Storms Are Growing More Fearsome, More Often
description: The Friday storm that produced vast flooding in New York City started out earlier in the week as an unremarkable — if unpredictable — weather system.
content: At first, it looked as if New York would simply be grazed by light rain on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jiayang Fan
title: How to Keep History From Going Down the Memory Hole in China
description: In “Sparks,” the journalist Ian Johnson chronicles the methods and motivations of the activists trying to preserve a record of the atrocities of the past.
content: By now, it is almost clichéd to compare political misrule to the dystopia that Orwell conjured through the story of the low-ranking functionary Winston Smith in “1984,” but so many aspects of the novel have come true in today’s China — from mass surveillance to fury-inciting demagogy to President Xi Jinping’s declaration that the Communist Party’s rule is “the conclusion of history” — that it may appear to preclude, as it ultimately did for Smith, the possibility of resistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: On Anniversary of Illegal Annexation, Russia Strikes Ukrainian Region It Claims as Its Own
description: As little territory changes hands on the battlefield, President Vladimir Putin of Russia and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine both signal that they are prepared to keep fighting.
content: Russia launched a missile attack on a region in southern Ukraine that it claims as its own on Saturday, wounding at least five people, a day after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered dueling speeches that underlined their determination to keep fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Should I Get a Smart Lock for My House, or Stick With a Deadbolt?
description: ‘Everything that gets locked, gets unlocked,’ said one professional. So it’s a matter of your preference and what your home can accommodate.
content: Q: My home has been broken into on more than one occasion in recent years, and I’m looking for the best way to secure it. Should I stick with a traditional deadbolt lock with a key, or should I upgrade to a smart lock?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Shirky
title: A History of Content Creation, From the Blogosphere to Today
description: Taylor Lorenz’s “Extremely Online” charts the internet phenomena that have shaped the 21st century, focusing not on the platforms but on the users.
content: Early in “Extremely Online,” Taylor Lorenz’s terrific history of the online creator economy (so far), she tells the story of Heather Armstrong, a pioneering “mommy blogger” known as Dooce, on a horseback ride sponsored by a clothing brand in 2013. Saddling up is famously hard on unhabituated groins, and the eventual pain had Armstrong recalling breathing exercises she’d seen in a book on natural childbirth. Later she blogged that one of her defining images of the trip had been “hairy vaginas.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Anthropology Conference Drops a Panel Defending Sex as Binary
description: Organizers said the session did not have scientific merit and was harmful to transgender members. Critics of the move say the discipline is unfriendly to dissenting views on the subject.
content: For a big annual conference on anthropology, Kathleen Lowrey, an associate professor at the University of Alberta, put together several panelists around a controversial theme: that their discipline was in the midst of erasing discussions of sex, which they believe is binary — either male or female.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo and Gaya Gupta
title: Rep. Jamaal Bowman Pulls Fire Alarm in House Office Building
description: Mr. Bowman, a Democrat, pulled the alarm ahead of a rushed vote on a stopgap funding measure. Two investigations have been opened in the incident.
content: Representative Jamaal Bowman, Democrat of New York, pulled a fire alarm in the House Cannon office building on Saturday as his party was trying to delay a vote on a stopgap spending bill, prompting an evacuation of the building and investigations by the Capitol Police and the House Administration Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Make TV and Movies Weird Again
description: There’s a depressing sameness out there — but movies like ‘Bottoms’ are a beacon.
content: My favorite house-hunting and travel show is not on television. It’s on TikTok, from a creator going by the handle @sinisterpondbabe who has a series called “Cheap House Babe,” finding inexpensive, usually dilapidated houses in small towns across the country and taking the viewer along for a virtual tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Going Solo to a Wedding? Here’s How to Make the Best of It.
description: Attending a wedding alone can be anxiety-inducing. Here are some tips for having fun even when you don’t know most of the guests.
content: Lucy Mary Taylor lost touch with most of her classmates from Coleg Gwent in Newport, Wales, but she kept in close contact with her pal Gabrielle Lopategui. Ms. Lopategui, whom she met in 2010, was the first of her friends to marry, and Ms. Taylor felt honored to be invited to the wedding. But beside the bride, the groom and the bride’s parents, she would not know anybody there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Vjosa Isai
title: Modi’s Hindu Nationalism Stokes Tension in Indian Diaspora
description: The killing of a Canadian Sikh leader, carried out by what Canada described as Indian government agents, occurred amid widening divisions in the diaspora.
content: Lecture halls at Canadian and American universities have become battlegrounds for critics and defenders of Hindu nationalism, punctuated by threats of violence and even death. Temples of Sikhs and Hindus in Canada and Australia have been defaced with slogans harking back to India’s timeless divisions. Parades in two North American cities have featured displays celebrating episodes of brutal sectarian violence in India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson
title: Congress Narrowly Averts Shutdown as House Democrats Help Pass Stopgap Bill
description: In a stunning reversal, Speaker Kevin McCarthy pushed through a bill with Democratic votes to temporarily keep the government open. President Biden signed it late Saturday.
content: Congress narrowly averted a government shutdown on Saturday as the House, in a stunning turnabout, approved a stopgap plan to keep the federal government open until mid-November. After Senate passage, President Biden signed the bill shortly before midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: For Native American Tribes, Shutdown Stakes Are Especially High
description: Tribal governments are heavily dependent on federal funding because of treaties guaranteeing basic services.
content: On the Turtle Mountain Indian Reservation in North Dakota, the contingency planning started weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Trump’s Rivals Are Facing Loserdom. They Have a Long-Shot Option.
description: It may be hopeless, but DeSantis, Haley and others need a post-Iowa plan.
content: I’m not sure that an assembly of presidential candidates has ever given off stronger loser vibes, if I may use a word favored by the 45th president of the United States, than the Republicans who debated at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: How China’s Property Crisis Is Testing Its Too-Big-to-Fail Banks
description: Banks hold enormous amounts of real estate debt, and regulators are nervous. But a fast-moving crisis is unlikely because the government has extensive control of the system.
content: China’s giant banking system, the world’s largest, is heavily exposed to the real estate crisis: Nearly 40 percent of all bank loans are related to property. And pressure is building on those banks as dozens of real estate developers have defaulted or missed payments on overseas bonds, led by China Evergrande, the world’s most indebted developer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Slovakia’s Election Could Echo in Ukraine. Here’s What to Expect.
description: A leader who has railed against NATO and sanctions on Russia appears poised for a strong showing. That could threaten Europe’s unity on support for Ukraine.
content: Voters in Slovakia headed to the polls on Saturday for an election that represents more than just a vote in a small Central European nation with less than six million people. It could also alter the contours of what has been a mostly united front in Europe against Russia’s war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Great Fall
description: Ahmed Bayoumi makes his New York Times debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Hello, puzzlers, and what a rare treat to see you all on a Saturday! I’m filling in today for your usual weekend columnist, Caitlin Lovinger. I’ll try to leave everything in good shape, and give you all the impression that I’m as expert a solver as she is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio, Alicia Parlapiano, Jasmine C. Lee, Helmuth Rosales, Molly Cook Escobar, Allison McCann and Karen Yourish
title: How Each Member Voted on the House Stopgap Spending Measure
description: See how each member of the House of Representatives voted on a measure to keep the government open through mid-November.
content: See how each member of the House of Representatives voted on a measure to keep the government open through mid-November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Yourish and Lazaro Gamio
title: How the Shutdown Holdouts Have Antagonized McCarthy Before
description: Some of Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s most persistent tormentors assembled Friday to defeat a stopgap spending measure to avoid a government shutdown, the latest episode in a pattern of blocking his efforts in the House.
content: Some of Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s most persistent tormentors assembled Friday to defeat a stopgap spending measure to avoid a government shutdown, the latest episode in a pattern of blocking his efforts in the House.
source.name: The New York Times
